citeinfo.title: Stratigraphic horizon grids for the 3D petroleum systems model of the Williston Basin, USA
Modeling the maturation history of the stacked petroleum systems of the Williston Basin, USA

serinfo.sername: Journal of Marine and Petroleum Geology

descript.abstract: The stratigraphic horizon grids were generated by picking formation tops in 16,200 borehole geophysical logs and interpolating between them in the Williston Basin of North Dakota, South Dakota, and Montana. Collectively, the horizon grids outline the structural framework of the Williston Basin from the ground surface to the crystalline basement. The grids define the boundary surfaces between geologic layers in the 3D petroleum systems model. Not every horizon in the petroleum systems model, however, ties to a specific interpreted set of formation tops (see the ‘Williston_Basin_data_overview.csv’ table to see which horizons were derived from interpreted formation tops). Some horizons were split/calculated to accommodate source rock intervals or net evaporite thicknesses (denoted halite or anhydrite in the file name suffix). Although some lithostratigraphic units are not present throughout the entire area of interest (AOI), the petroleum systems model requires that each grid cover the entire AOI. Another requirement for the petroleum systems model is that each horizon grid be assigned a geologic age. This is a child item of a larger data release titled "Data release for the 3D petroleum systems model of the Williston Basin, USA".
descript.purpose: The stratigraphic horizon grids are a required input for running the 3D petroleum systems model. They provide constraints on burial history, and they serve as the bounding framework for defining distinct lithologic packages. These data are also useful for visualizing the regional-scale (basin-scale) subsurface stratigraphic and structural architecture. Collectively, these horizons represent a 3D model of the subsurface, and modeling steps were taken to ensure that horizons do not intersect or cross one another.
descript.supplinf:
There are 47 horizon grids. The file naming convention uses the prefix “HRZ” to indicate horizon, the three-digit numerical code represents the geologic age assignment used in the model (millions of years ago, Ma), and the lithostratigraphic unit name assigned to the horizon comes after the underscore. See the “Williston_Basin_data_overview.csv” data table and accompanying metadata for more details on file naming convention. All grids are in a conventional depth orientation for petroleum systems modeling, where elevation values below the mean sea level reference datum are positive and values above the mean sea level reference datum are negative. Below is a list of all 47 horizon grids used in the model:
HRZ000_Topography.asc HRZ020_Neogene_unconformity.asc HRZ050_Paleogene_unconformity.asc HRZ070_Pierre.asc HRZ097_Mowry.asc HRZ125_InyanKara.asc HRZ145_Swift_lower.asc HRZ170_Rierdon.asc HRZ183_Piper.asc HRZ197_Dunham_salt.asc HRZ201_Spearfish.asc HRZ228_Opeche.asc HRZ254_Spearfish_lower.asc HRZ307_Tyler.asc HRZ313_Tyler_upper_source_base.asc HRZ315_Tyler_lower_source_top.asc HRZ323_Otter.asc HRZ330_Kibbey.asc HRZ335_Charles.asc HRZ338_Charles_halite_base.asc HRZ339_Charles_anhydrite.asc HRZ340_MissionCanyon.asc HRZ344_MissionCanyon_anhydrite_base.asc HRZ348_Madison_source.asc HRZ349_Lodgepole.asc HRZ357_Bakken_upper.asc HRZ362_Bakken_middle.asc HRZ364_Bakken_lower.asc HRZ368_ThreeForks.asc HRZ372_Duperow.asc HRZ374_Duperow_anhydrite_base.asc HRZ377_DawsonBay.asc HRZ382_Prairie_upper.asc HRZ383_Prairie_evaporite.asc HRZ388_Winnipegosis.asc HRZ408_Ashern.asc HRZ419_Interlake.asc HRZ445_RedRiver_uppermost.asc HRZ447_RedRiver_anhydrite.asc HRZ448_RedRiver_upper.asc HRZ450_RedRiver_kukersite.asc HRZ452_RedRiver_lower.asc HRZ458_Winnipeg.asc HRZ463_Icebox_GovernmentCreek.asc HRZ467_Winnipeg_lower.asc HRZ470_Deadwood.asc HRZ542_Basement.asc

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

idinfo.datacred: Christopher Skinner for review of spatial components and data architecture, Rand Gardner for review of data associated with the petroleum systems model.
idinfo.native: This dataset was developed on Windows 10 Enterprise using Kingdom, PetroMod, ArcGIS Pro, Microsoft Excel, and Jupyter Notebooks.

attracc.attraccr: The attribute reported in these data are the subsea elevations of the stratigraphic horizons. No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted. The accuracy of the attribute is dependent on both the vertical and horizontal positional accuracy of the formation tops and the original IHS Markit ® (2022) data sources they were derived from.

dataqual.logic: The grids have been spot checked for consistency. There are no duplications or omissions of data elements. No formal topology tests were conducted, but all the grids are readable in ArcGIS Pro without topology errors.
dataqual.complete: The data extend over a large portion of the USGS Williston Basin Province (Province 31).

horizpa.horizpar: A formal assessment of the horizontal positional accuracy of the original IHS Markit ® (2022) data source has not been conducted. The horizontal position of the well points is derived from various sources filed with state agencies. These include land plat maps, drilling permits, drilling reports, and directional drilling surveys.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal assessment of the vertical positional accuracy of the original IHS Markit ® (2022) data source has not been conducted. Vertical accuracy of the formation top on a borehole log is generally considered to range between 10 to 100s of feet, but this depends on many factors, including when the well was drilled and if a directional survey was acquired during the drilling.

citeinfo.title: Enerdeq US Well History and Production: database available from IHS Markit ®, 2022

srcinfo.srccontr: The horizontal position and the vertical datum applied to all the wells in this data release is originally derived from the IHS Markit ® (2022) data source

citeinfo.title: US Well Log Catalog: database available from IHS Markit ®, 2022
citeinfo.geoform: digital .las and raster image wireline log files

srcinfo.srccontr: Formation tops were picked on borehole geophysical logs downloaded from the IHS Markit ® (2022) US Well Log Catalog.

citeinfo.title: 1/3rd arc-second Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) - USGS National Map 3DEP Downloadable Data Collection

srcinfo.srccontr: Tiled rasters from the 3D Elevation Program (3DEP) were used to generate the "HRZ000_Topography.asc" horizon grid. The rasters were mosaiced into a single, seamless raster, transformed into the Albers projection, and down-sampled to ~2000 ft cell size resolution.

citeinfo.title: Quaternary sediment thickness and bedrock topography of the glaciated United States east of the Rocky Mountains

srcinfo.srccontr: Quaternary sediment thickness map was used to generate the grid "HRZ020_Neogene_unconformity.asc" by subtracting the thickness values from the topography grid ("HRZ000_Topography.asc").

procstep.procdesc: The stratigraphic horizons were generated by interpolating between formation tops picked on borehole geophysical logs. The interpolation method used in generating each horizon was done using Kingdom’s “Flex Gridding” algorithm and setting the data fit to preserve minimum curvature. Using this method, the highs and lows produced in the generated horizon may be projected higher and lower than the highest and lowest input formation top values. This processing step was used to generate a set of four “anchor” horizons: “HRZ097_Mowry.asc”, “HRZ330_Kibbey.asc”, “HRZ357_Bakken_upper.asc”, “HRZ445_RedRiver_uppermost.asc”. These grids were selected as “anchors” due to high quality geophysical log markers, making formation top picking rapid and robust over a broad region and providing good constraints in the interpolation process.

To ensure that each horizon does not cross or intersect with overlying and underlying horizons, we used a stacked isochore grid method where isochore grids were generated by interpolating the true vertical thickness (TVT) between formation tops and then subtracted and added in sequence from the ground surface horizon (“HRZ000_Topography.asc”) down to the basement (“HRZ542_Basement.asc”). This is an iterative process and the anchor horizons generated in the previous step provide the framework for building the additional horizon grids above and below.

Not all the horizon grids tie to a specific set of formation tops. Some horizons were split/calculated to accommodate source rock intervals or net evaporite thicknesses (denoted halite or anhydrite in the file name suffix). This step was completed in the PetroMod software, and it takes the two bounding horizon grids and splits them proportionally.

Each horizon is assigned a geologic age, which is identified using the numerical component of the file name prefix. An essential requirement in all 3D petroleum systems models is that the geographic extent of each stratigraphic horizon covers the entire area of interest (AOI). In some cases, the represented lithostratigraphic unit (e.g., the Bakken Formation) has a geographical extent that is smaller than the AOI and it is therefore necessary to assign the formation to a chronostratigraphic horizon that covers the entire AOI.
All the horizon grids were then clipped to an AOI polygon that approximates the outline of the Williston Basin.

overview.eaover: A data bundle of 47 ASCII raster files recording the elevation of stratigraphic horizons relative to mean sea level. Positive values represent elevations below mean sea level, and negative values represent elevations above sea level. Collectively, the values range from 13,792 ft in the deepest horizon grid (“HRZ542_Basement.asc”) to -3,547 in the shallowest horizon grid (“HRZ000_Topography.asc”). No data or null values are represented with a -9999 value.

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata, and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
